"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Hello Everyone!!! Day 6 Done 🎉 my sixth assignment . Iam also proud to say this summit my  exciting that part. thanks a lot from Rakshana mam. Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. How do you decide on the right injection method for your projects? Let’s discuss. hashtag#SpringFramework hashtag#DependencyInjection hashtag#JavaDevelopment

"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. How do you decide on the right injection method for your projects? Let’s discuss. hashtag#SpringFramework hashtag#DependencyInjection hashtag#JavaDevelopment

"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

Hello Everyone!!! Day 3 Done 🎉 I am also completed my third day 🎯journey about from java. continue to success ful my life. Here's a detailed explanation of operators and control statements in Java. Operators:Java has various operators that can be used to perform operations on variables and values. Here are the different types of operators:1. *Arithmetic Operators*: These operators are used to perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. - `+` (addition) - `-` (subtraction) - `*` (multiplication) - `/` (division) - `%` (modulus)2. *Assignment Operators*: These operators are used to assign a value to a variable. - `=` (assignment) - `+=` (addition assignment) - `-=` (subtraction assignment) - `*=` (multiplication assignment) - `/=` (division assignment) - `%=` (modulus assignment)3. *Comparison Operators*: These operators are used to compare two values. - `==` (equal to) - `!=` (not equal to) - `>` (greater than) - `<` (less than) - `>=` (greater than or equal to) - `<=` (less than or equal to)4. *Logical Operators*: These operators are used to perform logical operations. - `&&` (logical and) - `||` (logical or) - `!` (logical not)5. *Bitwise Operators*: These operators are used to perform bitwise operations. - `&` (bitwise and) - `|` (bitwise or) - `^` (bitwise xor) - `~` (bitwise not) - `<<` (left shift) - `>>` (right shift) - `>>>` (unsigned right shift)Control Statements:Control statements are used to control the flow of a program's execution. Here are the different types of control statements:1. *If-Else Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.2. *Switch Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code based on the value of a variable.3. *While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.4. *For Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a specified number of iterations.5. *Do-While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.6. *Break Statement*: This statement is used to terminate the execution of a loop or switch statement.7. *Continue Statement*: This statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop and move on to the next iteration.hashtag#Javalifehashtag#CodingfromJavahashtag#CybernautEdu-tech

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. How do you decide on the right injection method for your projects? Let’s discuss. hashtag#SpringFramework hashtag#DependencyInjection hashtag#JavaDevelopment

"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

Hello Everyone!!! Day 3 Done 🎉 I am also completed my third day 🎯journey about from java. continue to success ful my life. Here's a detailed explanation of operators and control statements in Java. Operators:Java has various operators that can be used to perform operations on variables and values. Here are the different types of operators:1. *Arithmetic Operators*: These operators are used to perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. - `+` (addition) - `-` (subtraction) - `*` (multiplication) - `/` (division) - `%` (modulus)2. *Assignment Operators*: These operators are used to assign a value to a variable. - `=` (assignment) - `+=` (addition assignment) - `-=` (subtraction assignment) - `*=` (multiplication assignment) - `/=` (division assignment) - `%=` (modulus assignment)3. *Comparison Operators*: These operators are used to compare two values. - `==` (equal to) - `!=` (not equal to) - `>` (greater than) - `<` (less than) - `>=` (greater than or equal to) - `<=` (less than or equal to)4. *Logical Operators*: These operators are used to perform logical operations. - `&&` (logical and) - `||` (logical or) - `!` (logical not)5. *Bitwise Operators*: These operators are used to perform bitwise operations. - `&` (bitwise and) - `|` (bitwise or) - `^` (bitwise xor) - `~` (bitwise not) - `<<` (left shift) - `>>` (right shift) - `>>>` (unsigned right shift)Control Statements:Control statements are used to control the flow of a program's execution. Here are the different types of control statements:1. *If-Else Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.2. *Switch Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code based on the value of a variable.3. *While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.4. *For Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a specified number of iterations.5. *Do-While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.6. *Break Statement*: This statement is used to terminate the execution of a loop or switch statement.7. *Continue Statement*: This statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop and move on to the next iteration.hashtag#Javalifehashtag#CodingfromJavahashtag#CybernautEdu-tech

This is a 6-month remote contract position, with an urgent need for an offshore resource based in India.Job Title: Java / Kafka ConsultantLocation: Remote in IndiaDuration: 6+ months contractRole Description:The role requires a minimum of four years of experience in setting up Kafka-based big data solutions using Kafka, Spark, and Scala.Strong expertise in Kafka architecture and managing single and multi-node Kafka clusters on VMs, Docker, and Kubernetes is essential.Experience with Confluent Platform is a must, along with a deep understanding of Kafka Producer/Consumer APIs, Stream Processing, and KSQL.Responsibilities include platform monitoring, creating key performance metrics, and maintaining cluster health, utilization, and performance.The role involves capacity planning, upgrading hardware/software, and automating administration tasks using tools like Terraform, Ansible, and CI/CD pipelines.Security configurations such as SSL encryption, SASL LDAP authentication, and Kafka ACL-based authorization must be implemented.Hands-on experience in public cloud environments such as Azure, AWS, or GCP is preferred.The candidate should be available for on-call support, shift work, and occasional weekend availability as required.Strong communication, troubleshooting, and documentation skills are necessary, along with the ability to conduct knowledge transfer sessions.Preferred qualifications include Confluent Kafka certification, cloud certifications (e.g., Azure), and experience with microservices, REST APIs, and containerization.Please reach out to me at +919899634637 or jbhatia@forcecraver.com to discuss further.Follow Jitender Bhatia Forcecraver Technologies for more job updates.

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. "If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Hello Everyone!!! Day 6 Done 🎉 my sixth assignment . Iam also proud to say this summit my  exciting that part. thanks a lot from Rakshana mam. Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

Hello Everyone!!! Day 3 Done 🎉 I am also completed my third day 🎯journey about from java. continue to success ful my life. Here's a detailed explanation of operators and control statements in Java. Operators:Java has various operators that can be used to perform operations on variables and values. Here are the different types of operators:1. *Arithmetic Operators*: These operators are used to perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. - `+` (addition) - `-` (subtraction) - `*` (multiplication) - `/` (division) - `%` (modulus)2. *Assignment Operators*: These operators are used to assign a value to a variable. - `=` (assignment) - `+=` (addition assignment) - `-=` (subtraction assignment) - `*=` (multiplication assignment) - `/=` (division assignment) - `%=` (modulus assignment)3. *Comparison Operators*: These operators are used to compare two values. - `==` (equal to) - `!=` (not equal to) - `>` (greater than) - `<` (less than) - `>=` (greater than or equal to) - `<=` (less than or equal to)4. *Logical Operators*: These operators are used to perform logical operations. - `&&` (logical and) - `||` (logical or) - `!` (logical not)5. *Bitwise Operators*: These operators are used to perform bitwise operations. - `&` (bitwise and) - `|` (bitwise or) - `^` (bitwise xor) - `~` (bitwise not) - `<<` (left shift) - `>>` (right shift) - `>>>` (unsigned right shift)Control Statements:Control statements are used to control the flow of a program's execution. Here are the different types of control statements:1. *If-Else Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.2. *Switch Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code based on the value of a variable.3. *While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.4. *For Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a specified number of iterations.5. *Do-While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.6. *Break Statement*: This statement is used to terminate the execution of a loop or switch statement.7. *Continue Statement*: This statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop and move on to the next iteration.hashtag#Javalifehashtag#CodingfromJavahashtag#CybernautEdu-tech

Hello Everyone!!! Day 2 Done 🎉 I am also proud to summit my assignment. 🎯 learning object from java. thanks a lot from Rakshana mam. second topic was variables & Data types. Here's a detailed explanation of variables and data types in Java:Variables:In Java, a variable is a name given to a memory location that stores a value. Variables are used to store and manipulate data in a program.*Types of Variables*There are several types of variables in Java:1. *Local Variables*: Declared within a method or block. They are only accessible within that method or block.2. *Instance Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method. They are associated with an instance of the class.3. *Static Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method, with the `static` keyword. They are shared by all instances of the class.4. *Parameter Variables*: Passed to a method when it is called.Data Types:In Java, data types determine the size and type of value that a variable can hold. There are two main categories of data types:1. *Primitive Data Types*: These are built-in data types that are not objects. Examples include `int`, `double`, `boolean`, etc.2. *Reference Data Types*: These are objects that store references to the actual data in memory. Examples include `String`, `Array`, etc.*Primitive Data Types*Here are the eight primitive data types in Java:1. *byte*: 8-bit signed integer, range: -128 to 1272. *short*: 16-bit signed integer, range: -32,768 to 32,7673. *int*: 32-bit signed integer, range: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,6474. *long*: 64-bit signed integer, range: -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,8075. *float*: 32-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±3.4e386. *double*: 64-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±1.8e3087. *boolean*: true or false value8. *char*: 16-bit Unicode character, range: '\u0000' to '\uffff'hashtag#Codeschallengehashtag#Codingjavahashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. How do you decide on the right injection method for your projects? Let’s discuss. hashtag#SpringFramework hashtag#DependencyInjection hashtag#JavaDevelopment

"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

Hello Everyone!!! Day 3 Done 🎉 I am also completed my third day 🎯journey about from java. continue to success ful my life. Here's a detailed explanation of operators and control statements in Java. Operators:Java has various operators that can be used to perform operations on variables and values. Here are the different types of operators:1. *Arithmetic Operators*: These operators are used to perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. - `+` (addition) - `-` (subtraction) - `*` (multiplication) - `/` (division) - `%` (modulus)2. *Assignment Operators*: These operators are used to assign a value to a variable. - `=` (assignment) - `+=` (addition assignment) - `-=` (subtraction assignment) - `*=` (multiplication assignment) - `/=` (division assignment) - `%=` (modulus assignment)3. *Comparison Operators*: These operators are used to compare two values. - `==` (equal to) - `!=` (not equal to) - `>` (greater than) - `<` (less than) - `>=` (greater than or equal to) - `<=` (less than or equal to)4. *Logical Operators*: These operators are used to perform logical operations. - `&&` (logical and) - `||` (logical or) - `!` (logical not)5. *Bitwise Operators*: These operators are used to perform bitwise operations. - `&` (bitwise and) - `|` (bitwise or) - `^` (bitwise xor) - `~` (bitwise not) - `<<` (left shift) - `>>` (right shift) - `>>>` (unsigned right shift)Control Statements:Control statements are used to control the flow of a program's execution. Here are the different types of control statements:1. *If-Else Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.2. *Switch Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code based on the value of a variable.3. *While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.4. *For Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a specified number of iterations.5. *Do-While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.6. *Break Statement*: This statement is used to terminate the execution of a loop or switch statement.7. *Continue Statement*: This statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop and move on to the next iteration.hashtag#Javalifehashtag#CodingfromJavahashtag#CybernautEdu-tech

Hello Everyone!!! Day 2 Done 🎉 I am also proud to summit my assignment. 🎯 learning object from java. thanks a lot from Rakshana mam. second topic was variables & Data types. Here's a detailed explanation of variables and data types in Java:Variables:In Java, a variable is a name given to a memory location that stores a value. Variables are used to store and manipulate data in a program.*Types of Variables*There are several types of variables in Java:1. *Local Variables*: Declared within a method or block. They are only accessible within that method or block.2. *Instance Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method. They are associated with an instance of the class.3. *Static Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method, with the `static` keyword. They are shared by all instances of the class.4. *Parameter Variables*: Passed to a method when it is called.Data Types:In Java, data types determine the size and type of value that a variable can hold. There are two main categories of data types:1. *Primitive Data Types*: These are built-in data types that are not objects. Examples include `int`, `double`, `boolean`, etc.2. *Reference Data Types*: These are objects that store references to the actual data in memory. Examples include `String`, `Array`, etc.*Primitive Data Types*Here are the eight primitive data types in Java:1. *byte*: 8-bit signed integer, range: -128 to 1272. *short*: 16-bit signed integer, range: -32,768 to 32,7673. *int*: 32-bit signed integer, range: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,6474. *long*: 64-bit signed integer, range: -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,8075. *float*: 32-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±3.4e386. *double*: 64-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±1.8e3087. *boolean*: true or false value8. *char*: 16-bit Unicode character, range: '\u0000' to '\uffff'hashtag#Codeschallengehashtag#Codingjavahashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!

|Simplifying Dependency Injection in Spring| Dependency Injection (DI) is a cornerstone of the Spring Framework, promoting clean and modular code. Here's a quick overview of its types: 1. Constructor Injection: Dependencies are passed via constructors. Perfect for mandatory dependencies and ensuring immutability. 2. Setter Injection: Dependencies are set via setter methods. Great for optional or changeable dependencies during runtime. 3. Field Injection: Dependencies are directly injected into class fields using annotations like @Autowired. While concise, it tightly couples the code to Spring. Choosing the right approach depends on your use case. Constructor injection is favored for its clarity and immutability, while setter injection offers flexibility, and field injection simplifies implementation. How do you decide on the right injection method for your projects? Let’s discuss. hashtag#SpringFramework hashtag#DependencyInjection hashtag#JavaDevelopment

"If you want to truly learn something, you need to understand its basics in depth." Today, I want to share how I learned about Threads in Java and my key takeaways.🔹 What is a Thread? A thread is an execution context, which is all the information a CPU needs to execute a stream of instructions.Suppose you're reading a book, and you want to take a break right now, but you want to be able to come back and resume reading from the exact point where you stopped. One way to achieve that is by jotting down the page number, line number, and word number. So your execution context for reading a book is these 3 numbers.If you have a roommate, and she's using the same technique, she can take the book while you're not using it, and resume reading from where she stopped. Then you can take it back, and resume it from where you were.Threads work in the same way. A CPU is giving you the illusion that it's doing multiple computations at the same time. It does that by spending a bit of time on each computation. It can do that because it has an execution context for each computation. Just like you can share a book with your friend, many tasks can share a CPU.On a more technical level, an execution context (therefore a thread) consists of the values of the CPU's registers.

Hello Everyone!!! Day 8 Done 🎉 my Eighth assignment. I am also proud to  say  this entertainment. 🎯 learning about from java.INHERITANCE:Inheritance is a fundamental concept in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. Here's a detailed explanation of inheritance in Java:Inheritance is a mechanism in Java that allows one class to inherit the properties and behavior of another class. The class that is being inherited is called the superclass or parent class, and the class that is doing the inheriting is called the subclass or child class.Types of InheritanceThere are several types of inheritance in Java:1. *Single Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a single superclass.2. *Multilevel Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from a superclass that itself inherits from another superclass.3. *Hierarchical Inheritance*: A superclass is inherited by multiple subclasses.4. *Multiple Inheritance*: A subclass inherits from multiple superclasses. (Not directly supported in Java, but can be achieved using interfaces)Benefits of Inheritance1. *Code Reusability*: Inheritance allows for code reusability, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass.2. *Easier Maintenance*: Inheritance makes it easier to maintain and modify code, as changes to the superclass can be automatically inherited by the subclass.3. *Improved Readability*: Inheritance can improve the readability of code, as the subclass can inherit the properties and behavior of the superclass without having to duplicate code.hashtag#Codinglifehashtag#JavaJourneyhashtag#Codeschallenge

Encapsulation:Encapsulation is a fundamental concept in Java that binds together the data and the methods that manipulate that data, and keeps both safe from outside interference and misuse. Here's a detailed explanation of encapsulation in Java:Encapsulation is a mechanism of wrapping the data (variables) and the methods (functions) together as a single unit, which is called a class. This helps to protect the data from external interference and misuse.Benefits of Encapsulation1. *Data Hiding*: Encapsulation helps to hide the data from external sources, which makes it secure.2. *Code Reusability*: Encapsulation promotes code reusability, as the code can be used in multiple programs.3. *Improved Code Organization*: Encapsulation helps to organize the code in a better way, as the data and methods are wrapped together in a single unit.To achieve encapsulation in Java, you need to follow these steps:1. *Declare the variables as private*: This will prevent the variables from being accessed directly from outside the class.2. *Provide public methods to access and modify the variables*: This will allow the variables to be accessed and modified in a controlled way.hashtag#cCodinglifehashtag#Javalearninghashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

Here's a detailed explanation of methods in Java:In Java, a method is a block of code that performs a specific task. It's a way to organize and reuse code, making your programs more modular and efficient.Types of MethodsThere are several types of methods in Java:1. *Instance Methods*: These methods are associated with an instance of a class and have access to the instance's variables.2. *Static Methods*: These methods belong to a class rather than an instance and can be called without creating an instance.3. *Abstract Methods*: These methods are declared in an abstract class and must be implemented . Constructor:A constructor in Java is a special method that is used to initialize objects when they are created. It has the same name as the class and does not have a return type, not even void.Types of ConstructorsThere are two types of constructors in Java:1. *No-Arg Constructor*: A constructor that does not take any arguments.2. *Parameterized Constructor*: A constructor that takes one or more arguments.hashtag#codinglifehashtag#Javajourneyhashtag#Cybernautlearning

Hello Everyone!!! Day 3 Done 🎉 I am also completed my third day 🎯journey about from java. continue to success ful my life. Here's a detailed explanation of operators and control statements in Java. Operators:Java has various operators that can be used to perform operations on variables and values. Here are the different types of operators:1. *Arithmetic Operators*: These operators are used to perform arithmetic operations such as addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division. - `+` (addition) - `-` (subtraction) - `*` (multiplication) - `/` (division) - `%` (modulus)2. *Assignment Operators*: These operators are used to assign a value to a variable. - `=` (assignment) - `+=` (addition assignment) - `-=` (subtraction assignment) - `*=` (multiplication assignment) - `/=` (division assignment) - `%=` (modulus assignment)3. *Comparison Operators*: These operators are used to compare two values. - `==` (equal to) - `!=` (not equal to) - `>` (greater than) - `<` (less than) - `>=` (greater than or equal to) - `<=` (less than or equal to)4. *Logical Operators*: These operators are used to perform logical operations. - `&&` (logical and) - `||` (logical or) - `!` (logical not)5. *Bitwise Operators*: These operators are used to perform bitwise operations. - `&` (bitwise and) - `|` (bitwise or) - `^` (bitwise xor) - `~` (bitwise not) - `<<` (left shift) - `>>` (right shift) - `>>>` (unsigned right shift)Control Statements:Control statements are used to control the flow of a program's execution. Here are the different types of control statements:1. *If-Else Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code if a condition is true.2. *Switch Statement*: This statement is used to execute a block of code based on the value of a variable.3. *While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.4. *For Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly for a specified number of iterations.5. *Do-While Loop*: This loop is used to execute a block of code repeatedly while a condition is true.6. *Break Statement*: This statement is used to terminate the execution of a loop or switch statement.7. *Continue Statement*: This statement is used to skip the current iteration of a loop and move on to the next iteration.hashtag#Javalifehashtag#CodingfromJavahashtag#CybernautEdu-tech

Hello Everyone!!! Day 2 Done 🎉 I am also proud to summit my assignment. 🎯 learning object from java. thanks a lot from Rakshana mam. second topic was variables & Data types. Here's a detailed explanation of variables and data types in Java:Variables:In Java, a variable is a name given to a memory location that stores a value. Variables are used to store and manipulate data in a program.*Types of Variables*There are several types of variables in Java:1. *Local Variables*: Declared within a method or block. They are only accessible within that method or block.2. *Instance Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method. They are associated with an instance of the class.3. *Static Variables*: Declared within a class, but outside any method, with the `static` keyword. They are shared by all instances of the class.4. *Parameter Variables*: Passed to a method when it is called.Data Types:In Java, data types determine the size and type of value that a variable can hold. There are two main categories of data types:1. *Primitive Data Types*: These are built-in data types that are not objects. Examples include `int`, `double`, `boolean`, etc.2. *Reference Data Types*: These are objects that store references to the actual data in memory. Examples include `String`, `Array`, etc.*Primitive Data Types*Here are the eight primitive data types in Java:1. *byte*: 8-bit signed integer, range: -128 to 1272. *short*: 16-bit signed integer, range: -32,768 to 32,7673. *int*: 32-bit signed integer, range: -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,6474. *long*: 64-bit signed integer, range: -9,223,372,036,854,775,808 to 9,223,372,036,854,775,8075. *float*: 32-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±3.4e386. *double*: 64-bit floating-point number, range: approximately ±1.8e3087. *boolean*: true or false value8. *char*: 16-bit Unicode character, range: '\u0000' to '\uffff'hashtag#Codeschallengehashtag#Codingjavahashtag#CybernautEdu-Tech

I am still hiring!  We need an experienced modern C++ developer than groks low-latency, efficient code construction, and greenfield engineering practices.  We need a QA to partner with our existing QAs.  And we need a DevOps to work alongside our fantastic DevOps engineer.  That is 3 people right there for the US.Moreover, I will soon have 2 new US job requisitions open.  Both will be very challenging positions to fill, with very stringent requirements.  These two new reqs will be for a Sr Engineer and a Sr QA.  Here are the particulars for the Sr Engr:. Well versed in modern C++17/20 and current Boost libraries. Experienced with massive parallelism, such as DPDK, SPDK, HPX, OpenMP. Experienced with low-latency architectures and coding practices. At least 10 years of hands-on experience in C++ low-latency development, 15+ years overall. Works well with other very smart people, enjoys the zero->one creation process. Works well remotely, with minimal supervision, but outstanding resultsThe Sr QA is going to be challenge to find, IMHO.  Prove me wrong!. Understands modern C++ 17/20 - can read PRs, talk with developers. Java 17 experience, can run testcases in Java, compare to C++ results. Can work with Java coredumps easily. Understands sequential consistency, has working in large parallel environments. Has worked with software the decomposes a larger work into smaller tasks. Has a passion for correctness. Can script in python on Linux, well versed in using Linux command line tools. Loves to automated testing, regression testing. Working in a greenfield environment (not well specified, think start-up). Will to go deep in understanding how the code worksAll of these positions are pivotal for what we are developing here at FICO.  The bar is high, because your teammates are also exceptionally strong programmers.FICO is an excellent company to work for.  We are fully remote, with exceptional management (my boss Tom Traughber, and teammate Sachin Kulkarni).  My teams are creating the future platform for FICO.  It is truly greenfield, and we are fairly far along in the process, closing in on a beta release.The entry criteria for these 2 new positions (not yet posted), are very strict.  You will be working on pivotal software, which very high expectations of throughput, low latency, and 100% fidelity.  I mention this now because I need to get ahead of the curve!  If you are interested, please ping me.  We are creating the future here at FICO, alongside our existing top-of-the-market solutions.  Your teammates are looking forward to your arrival and successes!
